input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output:
Julius Caesar was a Roman general and statesman who played a significant role in the transition from the Roman Republic to the Roman Empire. He was born on July 13, 100 BC, in Rome, Italy.

Julius Caesar was a brilliant military commander and strategist who led the Roman army to victory in numerous battles, including the conquest of Gaul and the defeat of Pompey in the Roman Civil War. He was also a skilled politician who played a key role in the transformation of the Roman Republic into an empire.

Caesar was known for his ambitious and ruthless nature, which earned him many enemies, including the Roman senators who feared his growing power. He was assassinated on March 15, 44 BC, by a group of senators who were opposed to his increasing influence.

Despite his short life, Julius Caesar left a lasting legacy that continues to influence the world today. His military and political achievements, as well as his influence on the Roman Empire, have made him one of the most famous figures in history.

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output:
The Rolling Stones are an English rock band formed in London in 1962. Active for over 50 years, they are one of the most popular and enduring bands of the rock era. In the early 1960s, the Rolling Stones pioneered the gritty, heavier-driven sound that came to define hard rock. Their first stable line-up consisted of bandleader Brian Jones, pianist Ian Stewart, bassist Bill Wyman, drummer Charlie Watts, and vocalist Mick Jagger. Stewart was removed from the official line-up in 1963 but continued as a touring member until his death in 1985. The band's leader, Jones, was the group's primary songwriter prior to his death in 1969. After Jones' death, Keith Richards assumed the role as the primary songwriter.

The Rolling Stones have released 30 studio albums, 23 live albums, 12 soundtrack albums, and numerous compilations, and have sold over 250 million records worldwide, making them one of the world's best-selling music artists

output:
Michael Jordan is an American former professional basketball player who is widely regarded as one of the greatest basketball players of all time. He played 15 seasons in the National Basketball Association (NBA) for the Chicago Bulls and Washington Wizards. During his career, Jordan won six NBA championships, five Most Valuable Player (MVP) awards, ten All-NBA First Team designations, nine All-Defensive First Team honors, four NBA Finals MVP awards, and three All-Star Game MVP awards. He holds numerous NBA records, including career regular season scoring average (30.12 points per game), career playoff scoring average (33.45 points per game), and career playoff steals (898). Jordan is also a prominent businessman, having founded several successful companies, including the Michael Jordan Brand, which has become one of the most valuable and recognizable brands in the world.

input: Write a short biography of David Gilmour.
output:
David Jon Gilmour, CBE (born 6 March 1946) is an English singer, songwriter, composer, multi-instrumentalist, and record producer. He joined the progressive rock band Pink Floyd as guitarist and co-lead vocalist in 1968. He was a member of the band for 45 years, and was credited as a co-writer for all Pink Floyd albums. He was inducted into the US Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1996 as a member of Pink Floyd.

Gilmour has also released four solo albums: David Gilmour (1978), About Face (1984), On an Island (2006), and Rattle That Lock (2015). He has also released two live albums: Live in Gdansk (2008) and Live at Pompeii (2017). He has also released several collaborative albums, including The Division Bell (1994) with Pink Floyd, and Jokers & Mirth (2001) with Polly Samson.

input: Write a short biography of Oprah Winfrey.
output:
Oprah Winfrey is an American media executive, actress, talk show host, television producer, and philanthropist. She is best known for her talk show The Oprah Winfrey Show, which was the highest-rated television program of its kind in history and was nationally syndicated from 1986 to 2011 in Chicago. Dubbed the "Queen of All Media", she has been ranked the richest African-American, the greatest black philanthropist in American history, and is currently North America's first and only multi-billionaire black person. She has been recognized as one of the most influential women in the world.

Winfrey was born into poverty in rural Mississippi to a teenage single mother and later raised in inner-city Milwaukee. She has stated that she was molested during her childhood and early teens and became pregnant at 14; her son was born prematurely and died in infancy. Winfrey was then sent to live with the man she calls her father, Vernon Winfrey, a barber in Tennessee, and landed a job in radio while still in high school

input: Write a short biography of Rohit Sharma.
output:
Rohit Gurunath Sharma is an Indian international cricketer who captains the Indian national team in limited-overs formats. He is a right-handed batsman and an occasional right-arm off break bowler. He is regarded as one of the best limited-overs batsmen in the world.

## Early life

Rohit Sharma was born on 30 April 1987 in Bansod, Nagpur, Maharashtra, India. His father Gurunath Sharma was a caretaker at a transport depot and his mother Purnima Sharma was a homemaker. He has an elder brother named Vishal Sharma.

Sharma was a keen cricketer from a young age and was coached by his father. He attended Swami Vivekanand International School and Junior College in Borivali, Mumbai. He was a part of the Mumbai Cricket Association's (MCA) under-14 team in 2001.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output:
Cleopatra VII Philopator (Greek: Κλεοπάτρα Φιλοπάτωρ; 69 BC – 10 or 12 August 30 BC), known to history simply as Cleopatra, was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt, nominally a client state of the Roman Republic. After her father's death in 51 BC, she briefly ruled jointly with her brother Ptolemy XIII, until she regained sole power. As triumvirate ruler, she was a minor partner in a three-way alliance between Mark Antony, Octavian, and Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, known as the Second Triumvirate.

Cleopatra was a member of the Ptolemaic dynasty, a family of Greek origin that ruled Egypt after Alexander the Great's death during the Hellenistic period. The Ptolemies, throughout their dynasty, spoke Greek and wrote in the Greek language, although they ruled over a predominantly Egyptian population. The Weeknd is a Canadian singer, songwriter, and record producer. He is known for his distinctive music style, which incorporates elements of R&B, hip hop, and pop.

The Weeknd was born Abel Makkonen Tesfaye on February 16, 1990, in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. He grew up in Scarborough, a suburb of Toronto, and began his musical career in 2010, releasing his first mixtape, "House of Balloons," under the stage name The Weeknd.

input: Write a short biography of Idris Elba.
output:
Idrissa Akuna Elba OBE is an English actor, producer, musician, and DJ. He is known for roles including Stringer Bell in the HBO series The Wire, DCI John Luther in the BBC One series Luther, and Nelson Mandela in the biographical film Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom (2013).

### Early life

Elba was born on 6 September 1972 in Hackney, London, to Winston, a Sierra Leonean-Krio father, and Eve, a Ghanaian mother. He was raised in Canning Town, Newham, and Fordham, Essex. His father worked at Ford Dagenham and his mother cleaned houses. He has a younger brother, Winston, and a younger sister, Yvonne.

Elba attended the National Youth Music Theatre in London as a teenager, and then studied at the National Youth Theatre for a year. He then studied at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA).

Maathai was a professor at the University of Nairobi and a member of the National Council of Women of Kenya. The movement grew to include over 50,000 women and became a symbol of resistance against the oppressive regime of President Daniel arap Moi.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output:
Rosa Louise McCauley Parks (February 4, 1913 – October 24, 2005) was an American activist in the civil rights movement best known for her pivotal role in the Montgomery bus boycott. The United States Congress has called her "the first lady of civil rights" and "the mother of the freedom movement".

Parks was born in Tuskegee, Alabama. She was raised in Pine Level, Alabama, and Cleveland, Ohio. In 1933, she returned to Montgomery, Alabama, where she met and married Raymond Parks, an activist and leader in the African-American community. She joined the Montgomery NAACP chapter in 1943, and was often invited to speak at events. On December 1, 1955, Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat to a white passenger on a Montgomery city bus, an act that sparked a year-long boycott of the Montgomery bus system, organized by the black community. The boycott was a key event in the civil rights movement.

input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output:
Annelies Marie "Anne" Frank (German: [ˈanələs maˈʁiː ˈfʁaŋk]; 12 June 1929 – February or March 1945) was a German-born Jewish girl who documented her life in a diary from 1942 until she was 15 years old. She was born in Frankfurt, Germany, and spent most of her life in or around Amsterdam, Netherlands.

Frank was born in Germany, but her family moved to the Netherlands in 1933, when the Nazis gained power in Germany. In May 1940, the Netherlands was invaded by Nazi Germany and occupied. In 1942, the Franks went into hiding in an attic above her father's office in Amsterdam. For two years, Frank recorded events in her diary. She was 15 when she died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, near Hamburg, Germany.

Her father is of German and Irish descent, and her mother is of German and English ancestry. Reinhart was raised in Bay Village, Ohio, and attended Bay Village High School. She was a cheerleader for the Bay Village Rockets.

Reinhart began her career in 2012 with a small role in the film The Kings of Summer. She then appeared in the 2013 film Forever's End. In 2014, she appeared in the film Miss Stevens. output:
Cary Grant was an American actor who was known for his suave and debonair persona. He was born Archibald Alexander Leach on January 18, 1904, in Bristol, England, and began his career as a stage performer in the United States. Grant's film career began in the 1930s, and he quickly became one of Hollywood's most popular leading men. He starred in a number of classic films, including "His Girl Friday," "The Philadelphia Story," and "North by Northwest." Grant was known for his impeccable comedic timing and his ability to convey a sense of sophistication and elegance on screen. He was also known for his off-screen persona, which was often described as charming and witty. Grant was married four times, and had two children. He died on November 29, 1986, at the age of 82.

Lorde was a self-described "black, lesbian, mother, warrior, poet" and her work often explored themes of identity, race, and gender. She was a prominent figure in the feminist and civil rights movements of the 1970s and 1980s and her work continues to inspire activists and writers today.

Audre Lorde was born on February 18, 1934, in Harlem, New York City, to Caribbean immigrant parents. Her mother, Linda Gertrude Belmar, was from Barbados and her father, Reverend Theophilus Lorde, was from Grenada. Lorde was the youngest of three children and grew up in a working-class household. She attended public schools in Harlem and graduated from Hunter College High School in 1952.

input: Write a short biography of Novak Djokovic.
output:
Novak Djokovic is a Serbian professional tennis player. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.

### 1987–2006: Early life and junior career

Djokovic was born on 22 May 1987 in Belgrade, SFR Yugoslavia (now Serbia). He is the son of Srdjan and Dijana Djokovic. His father is a former handball player, and his mother is a pharmacist. He has two younger brothers, Marko and Djordje, and a younger sister, Jelena. Djokovic was introduced to tennis at the age of four by his father, who was his first coach. He began playing competitively at the age of eight.

Djokovic was a successful junior player, winning the Wimbledon boys' singles title in 2005 and the Australian Open boys' singles title in 2006. He also reached the final of the French Open boys' singles title in 2005.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output:
Indira Gandhi was the first and only female Prime Minister of India. She was born on November 19, 1917, in Allahabad, India. She was the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, the first Prime Minister of India, and Kamala Nehru. She was educated at the Lady Irwin School in New Delhi and later at Oxford University in England.

After completing her education, Indira Gandhi returned to India and became involved in politics. She was elected to the Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Indian Parliament, in 1964 and served as the Minister of Information and Broadcasting from 1966 to 1967. In 1967, she was appointed as the Minister of Railways and Communications, and in 1969, she became the Minister of Food and Agriculture.

In 1971, Indira Gandhi became the Prime Minister of India, making her the first and only female Prime Minister in the country's history. During her tenure as Prime Minister, she implemented several major economic and social reforms, including the nationalization of banks and insurance

input: Write a short biography of Amelia Earhart.
output:
Amelia Mary Earhart was an American aviation pioneer and author. She was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. She received the Distinguished Flying Cross for this record-setting flight. Earhart was also the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to the U.S. mainland. She set many other records, wrote best-selling books about her flying experiences, and was instrumental in the formation of The Ninety-Nines, an organization for female pilots.

input: Write a short biography of Shawn Mendes.
output:
Shawn Peter Raul Mendes (born August 8, 1998) is a Canadian singer-songwriter. He gained a following in 2013, posting song covers on the video-sharing application Vine. The following year, he caught the attention of artist manager Andrew Gertler and Island Records A&R Ziggy Chareton, which led to him signing a deal with the record label. He rose to prominence for his singles "Stitches" and "Treat You Better", which reached the top 20 in the US and top 10 in the UK. In 2015, Mendes released his self-titled debut studio album, which debuted atop the US Billboard 200, making him one of the youngest artists to ever top the chart. The album's lead single "Stitches" reached number one in the UK, Australia and the US, and was certified quadruple platinum in the US.

input: Write a short biography of Bryan Stevenson.
output:
Bryan A. Stevenson is an American lawyer and social justice activist. He is the founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative, a nonprofit organization that provides legal representation to prisoners who may have been wrongly convicted of crimes and those who have been denied fair treatment in the criminal justice system.

Stevenson was born on November 14, 1959, in Delaware, United States. He grew up in a middle-class family and attended public schools in the state. After graduating from high school, he attended Eastern University in Pennsylvania, where he earned a bachelor's degree in psychology. He then went on to earn a law degree from Harvard Law School in 1985.

Stevenson began his career as a public defender in Baltimore, Maryland, where he represented clients who could not afford private legal representation. He later moved to Alabama, where he worked as a staff attorney for the Southern Poverty Law Center. In 1989, he founded the Equal Justice Initiative, which has since become one of the leading civil rights organizations in the United States.

He also won a Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play for his Broadway debut in The Last Mile (1930).

Tracy was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the son of Caroline (née Fitzgerald) and John Edward Tracy, a salesman. His father was of Irish descent, and his mother was of Irish and French ancestry. He was raised in a Roman Catholic family.

Tracy's father was a heavy drinker and often abused his wife and children. Tracy's mother was a devout Catholic who took her children to Mass every Sunday. Tracy's father died when he was 12 years old.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output:
Rosa Luxemburg (March 5, 1871 – January 15, 1919) was a Polish-German Marxist theorist, philosopher, economist, and revolutionary socialist. She was a key figure in the development of Marxist theory, particularly through her analysis of imperialism and the accumulation of capital in the era of the globalization of capitalism. She was also a prominent leader in the German and international socialist movement.

Luxemburg was born in Zamość, in the Russian Empire (now Poland), to a Jewish family. She studied at the University of Zurich and the University of Berlin, where she was influenced by the works of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel and Ludwig Feuerbach. She became a member of the Social Democratic Party of the Kingdom of Poland and Lithuania (SDKPLL) in 1893 and was involved in the party's left-wing faction, the "Economists". In 1898, she co-founded the Social Democratic Party of the Kingdom of Poland and Lithuania (SDKPiL), which was later renamed the Polish Socialist Party (PPS).
